title: Fragment
content: A Fragment represents a behavior or a portion of user interface in a FragmentActivity. Its life cycle is onAttach(), onCreate(), onCreateView(), onActivityCreated(), onStart, onResume(), onPause(), onStop(), onDestroyView(), onDestroy(), onDetach()

title: Limited number of methods & Multidex
content:
The Dalvik Executable specification limits the total number of methods that can be referenced within a single DEX file to 65,536â€”including Android framework methods, library methods, and methods in your own code.

If the number of methods in your app is bugger than that you should apply multidex in the build.gradle file

title: When to use:
content:
• Use Service for tasks with no UI, but shouldn't be too long. Use threads within service for long tasks.
  • Use thread for long tasks in general
  • For tasks in parallel use Multiple threads (traditional mechanisms)
  • Use AsyncTasks for small task having to communicate with main thread.
  • For tasks in parallel use multiple instances of async tasks OR Executor

title: Difference between FutureTask & AsyncTask
content: FutureTask provides no callbacks, is not attached to the UI Thread and it is cancellable
